title: Dangers of Poor Sleep
content: Poor sleep can lead to increased risk of Alzheimer’s, mental health issues, and memory problems. Sleep disruption can also contribute to heart disease, cancer, and sexual dysfunction. Poor sleep can have penetrating effects on metabolism and genetics.

title: Strategies for Better Sleep
content: Strategies for sleeping more and sleeping better include managing exposure to blue light and caffeine, understanding the importance of REM sleep, and using sleep tracking wearables. Fasting can affect sleep, as can magnesium supplementation. Sleep deprivation can impact gut health.

title: Sleep & Covid-19
content: Sleep and immune function are interconnected, and good sleep hygiene is important for maintaining a strong immune system, especially during times of illness such as Covid-19.

title: Blue Light and Sleep
content: Blue light from devices like iPads can have a detrimental effect on sleep by delaying the release of melatonin, reducing REM sleep, and increasing alertness/physiological arousal in the brain. However, the impact of blue light on sleep may be less significant than previously thought, with device activation potentially playing a larger role in sleep disruption.

title: Caffeine and Sleep
content: Caffeine can disrupt sleep, but low-to-moderate caffeine consumption may also be associated with decreased risk of certain diseases. The timing and dose of caffeine consumption can affect its impact on sleep. Some people may metabolize caffeine more quickly than others, reducing its impact on their sleep.

title: REM Sleep Importance
content: REM sleep, or dream sleep, is increasingly recognized as important for health. While all stages of sleep are important and carry out different functions, REM sleep may have particular significance.

title: Importance of REM Sleep
content: REM sleep is particularly important for emotional/mental health. A lack of REM sleep seems to be more deadly than a lack of deep non-REM sleep. Evidence shows that for every 5% reduction in your REM sleep, there was a 13% increase in your mortality risk. Not just all cause mortality, but specific disease states such as cardiovascular disease risk. REM sleep was the single most predictive variable for your mortality risk.

title: Recommended Amount of REM Sleep
content: The recommendation for the average adult is for about 20% of your sleep to be consumed by REM sleep. This is also age-dependent to a degree.

title: Increasing REM Sleep
content: REM sleep is very difficult to modulate in an easy way. There’s a neurochemical in the brain called acetylcholine and REM sleep is powerfully regulated by acetylcholine. One idea to increase REM sleep involves temperature. For deep sleep, you cool the body to actually increase deep sleep. But to increase REM sleep, you need a temperature increase before you wake up.

title: Nature of REM Sleep
content: REM sleep is a state where the brain seems to get disconnected from the body in terms of autonomic regulation. Your brain’s systems of controlling and regulating your nervous system and your automatic functions all go out the window during REM sleep. Your temperature is also uncontrolled, you stop thermoregulating during REM sleep.

title: Sleep Tracking Wearables
content: Accuracy of sleep data relative to the gold standard of recordings in the sleep laboratory and form factor are two important criteria when it comes to wearables. Looking at the entire industry of sleep trackers, they are about 70% overall accurate in terms of the measurement of total sleep. The accuracy starts to decline for the different stages of sleep.

title: Relationship Between Fasting and Sleep
content: Some patients who do multi-day fasting (3+ days) will struggle with falling asleep and staying asleep at night. However, the sleep they do get actually seems remarkable. Heart rate variability goes up by 25- 50%, resting heart rate goes down, body temperature goes down. Deep sleep is 25%, REM sleep is 25%.

title: Improved Sleep Metrics and Fasting
content: Improved sleep metrics and people's subjective feeling of not being as sleepy as they typically would expect due to shorter fasting periods. If compliance to fasting would be better if people got better sleep, a pharmacological agent that blocks orexin might be beneficial.

title: Potential Therapeutic Implications
content: Several years ago, a company created a new sleep medication called Belsomra that targeted the orexin system. The thought was that insomnia patients might have artificially enhanced orexin at night. Unfortunately, the results were disappointing for insomnia patients. But it was wondered if Belsomra could be taken by fasters to quiet the orexin signal.

title: Restless Leg Syndrome
content: Restless leg syndrome (RLS) is a long-term disorder usually characterized by uncontrollable, and really uncomfortable, urge to move your legs (can also happen in other limbs like the arms). It effects between 5 to 15% of the population. The principle hypothesis is that it’s due a deficiency of dopamine in the brain. Another hypothesis is that RLS is due to an iron deficiency.

title: Magnesium Supplementation as a Sleep Aid
content: Magnesium supplementation is very commonly taken for sleep. The idea is that it helps relax the body and relax the muscles. However, there’s actually little good scientific evidence supporting the benefits. There is evidence that people who had sleep disruptions have a deficiency in magnesium (Mg). For those people deficient in Mg, supplementing with Mg could be part of the equation for better sleep.

title: The Relationship Between Sleep Deprivation and Gut Health
content: There is evidence starting to emerge about how sleep deprivation leads to poor gut health. Early data is showing that when you sleep deprive either human beings or animals, you see a shift in the gut microbiome balance away from the bacterial bent and more towards the fermented bent of the microbiome. That shift is interesting because there’s an association between poor health outcomes and a gut microbiome with a fermented bent.

title: The Next Evolution in Sleep Science and Technology
content: The next evolution in sleep science and technology could involve personalizing sleep medicine and creating technology that could act as a truly personalized sleep coach. The technology would ingest every piece of data about you, including bio-tracking data about your physiology, data about your mental state, and data out of your calendar. After ingesting all the data, for each specific day and evening it would create a personalized, tailored sleep prescription for you.

title: Questions About Super Agers
content: As we get older our sleep gets worse, and that seems to predict cognitive decline, e.g, an escalation in Alzheimer’s disease related proteins (tau and beta amyloid). But what about these centenarians who don’t see the same cognitive decline? Is sleep this countermeasure in all of this? Is sleep and new physiological blue zone?

title: Sleep Compression
content: There is an increasing pressure in modern society to sleep less. With unlimited resources and time, there is a desire to discover a technological way to develop a technique where sleep can be compressed down to four hours, four and a half hours, and it remains just as good as eight hours of sleep.
